thread.title: Wenger admits Chelsea defeat was 'difficult to watch'
thread.title_full: Wenger admits Chelsea defeat was 'difficult to watch' | Daily Mail Online

author: Kieran Gill for the Daily Mail
title: Wenger admits Chelsea defeat was 'difficult to watch'
text:
Arsene Wenger admitted he felt let down by his players in the defeat at Chelsea — and that could have a big effect on his future.
The 67-year-old Arsenal manager, who is heading into the final months of his contract, is basing his decision on signing a new deal on whether he feels he can still get the best out of his players.
That is the subject of fierce debate among Arsenal fans after this second Premier League defeat in just five days left Wenger’s side 12 points off the top.
Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger (left) gestures during his team's defeat to Chelsea
Arsenal players look on dejected after Chelsea's third goal at Stamford Bridge
Wenger accused his players of naivety and said: ‘That defeat against Watford had bigger consequences, maybe, than expected. We didn’t create enough. In the final third we didn’t look dangerous enough.
‘That was difficult to watch from upstairs. I’m not subdued. I’m disappointed and angry because we lost a very big game.’
Wenger was sat in the stands at Stamford Bridge as he continued to see out his touchline ban.
He is aware of unrest after TV cameras picked out anti-Wenger banners and Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain’s Twitter gaffe — he apologised after accidentally liking a post on social media that read: ‘Wenger needs to go.’
On his team’s predicament, he said: ‘The title’s slipped further out of our hands and there’s no hiding that.’
Wenger admitted he felt let down by his players in the Premier League encounter
